etymology.description: semantic: 木 (“tree; wood”) + phonetic: 登
etymology.interpretation: Combines 木 to indicate a plant/tree-related meaning, fitting its sense of citrus trees and their fruit. 登 supplies the pronunciation, whose historical reading was close to chéng, while the meaning settled on oranges and the orange color.

examples.chinese: 我喜欢橙色(我喜歡橙色)。
这棵橙树结了很多橙子(這棵橙樹結了很多橙子)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè kē chéngshù jiēle hěn duō chéngzi.
examples.english: This orange tree has borne many oranges.

examples.chinese: 请给我一杯鲜榨橙汁(請給我一杯鮮榨橙汁)。
examples.pinyin: Qǐng gěi wǒ yì bēi xiānzhà chéngzhī.
examples.english: Please give me a glass of freshly squeezed orange juice.
